best_practices: Prefer structured concurrency with task groups over detached tasks for automatic cancellation
Use actors for mutable shared state instead of locks or dispatch queues
Make types Sendable when passing across isolation boundaries to enable compile-time safety
Complete all actor state modifications before suspension points to prevent reentrancy bugs
anti_patterns: Using @MainActor as a blanket fix without justifying main thread necessity
Using @unchecked Sendable to silence warnings without proving thread safety
Keeping long-running work on actors that causes unnecessary contention
Assuming state is unchanged after await due to actor reentrancy

faq.question: Which Swift versions support concurrency features?
faq.answer: Async/await requires Swift 5.5+. Actors, task groups, and AsyncSequence shipped in Swift 5.5. Swift 6 enables complete strict concurrency checking by default.

faq.question: What are the main concurrency limits?
faq.answer: Tasks cannot exceed available thread pool. Actors serialize access which can cause contention. Task creation has overhead so avoid spawning thousands of tasks for trivial work.

faq.question: How does this integrate with existing code?
faq.answer: Use Task {} to bridge sync to async contexts. Wrap completion handlers with withCheckedContinuation. Gradually adopt concurrency module by module.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only provides guidance documentation. No code execution, no data access, no network calls. All advice is read-only guidance.

faq.question: Why do I see Sendable warnings?
faq.answer: Swift enforces compile-time thread safety. Types crossing isolation boundaries must be Sendable. Use value types, actors, or @unchecked Sendable only with documented justification.

faq.question: How does this compare to Combine?
faq.answer: Swift Concurrency provides structured, imperative async code. Combine uses reactive streams. For simple async operations, async/await is simpler. Combine excels at complex event transformations.
